title: Before the nip in the air disappears, here are 5 innovative jalebis you MUST try : How to, News - India Today
text:
Before the nip in the air disappears, here are 5 innovative jalebis you MUST try Forget the regular flour jalebis, and indulge in these easy-to-make-at-home treats. A + A - Jalebis are a must-have before winters go away for good. Picture courtesy: Pinterest/Kankana: Playful Cooking 
Freshly-made, hot jalebis, dripping chashni or rabdi--yes, that's just the stuff made of dreams. We're sure you had quite a bit of these throughout winter. But with spring approaching like a super-fast train, the weather isn't going to be ideal for gorging on jalebis for long. 
Jalebis, also known as zulbias, are one of the most popular snacks in South Asian countries. But having them in summer just isn't as satisfying as having them in winters. So before the nip in the air disappears completely, you should indulge a bit more. And if you're tired of having the same old flour jalebis soaked in sugar syrup, try these five instead. 
Apple 
Yes, you read that right. Apple jalebis are a hot favourite that you shouldn't miss out on. You'll need: 2 apples, peeled, cored, thinly sliced; 3/4 cup all-purpose flour; 1/2 tsp active dry yeast; 1/2 tsp sugar; 1 tbsp oil. Syrup: 1 cup sugar; 1 cup water; 1/4 tsp cardamom powder. Apple jalebis are sweet and succulent. Picture courtesy: Pinterest/Vegan Richa 
Mix the flour, yeast, sugar, and yeast together in a large bowl. Add some warm water, and make a smooth batter. Set the batter aside for half an hour. Boil the syrup ingredients together in a pan for 10 minutes. Set the syrup near the stove, so that you can transfer the fried jalebis easily. Heat some oil in a separate pan. Dip the apple slices in the batter, coat them properly, and fry them in the pan one or two at a time (over crowding will make them stick together). Once the slices are fried, take them off the oil, and soak them in the syrup for a few minutes. Follow the same process with the other slices. Serve the jalebis while they're hot. 
Also read: 3 chocolate-filled desserts that are guaranteed to make your period blues disappear 
Chocolate 
If you like everything chocolatey, this easy jalebi will be your best friend. To make the dish, you'll need: 1 cup flour; 2-3 tbsp cocoa powder; 1/2 tsp active dry yeast; 2 tbsp sugar; Water, as required; Oil, to fry. If you love chocolates and jalebis, this recipe is your dream come true. Picture courtesy: Pinterest/The Chocolate Jar 
Mix the flour, cocoa powder, yeast, and sugar in a large bowl. Add warm water gradually to make a smooth batter. Set the bowl aside to ferment it for half an hour. Heat oil in a pan. Transfer the batter into a piping bag, and press it out in spirals over the hot oil. Fry the jalebis till they're golden-brown. Take them out of the oil, and serve hot with chocolate syrup. 
Chhena 
Not many are familiar with chhena jalebis, but it's a popular delicacy in Bengal. The key with this one is the chhena--the fresher, the better. You'll need: 150 gms fresh chhena; 2 tsp milk; 1 tsp flour; 1/2 tsp baking powder; 1/2 tsp cardamom powder; Oil, to fry. Syrup: 1 cup sugar; 1 cup water; 1/4 tsp cardamom powder. Chhena jalebis are a popular sweet in Bengal. Picture courtesy: Pinterest/theflavoursofkitchen.com 
Mix together the chhena, flour, milk, cardamom powder and milk in a large bowl. Knead the mix into a smooth dough. Roll the dough into a long pipe or rope. Divide and cut the rope into equal stretches, and form them into coils or spirals. Boil the syrup ingredients together in a pan for 10 minutes. In a separate pan, heat oil to fry the jalebis. Add each spiral dough separately, and fry them till they're golden brown. Remove from the oil and dip them in the syrup for a minute. Serve warm with a sprinkle of chopped pistachios. 
Also read: Before oranges go out of season, here's a kheer recipe you've got to try 
Banana 
These jalebis are a Kumaoni speciality, and it's quite the standout because of the banana flavour. You'll need: 1 cup semolina or sooji; 2 cups yogurt; 1 ripe banana; 1 cup sugar; 3 tbsp chickpea flour or besan; 1/2 tsp cardamom powder; Oil, to fry. Banana jalebis are a Kumaoni speciality. Picture courtesy: Pinterest/Quite Good Food 
Mix together the flour and yogurt in a large bowl to make a batter. Set it aside for an hour to ferment. Grind the banana into a puree, and add it to the batter along with the sugar, besan, and cardamom powder. Transfer the batter into a piping bag. Heat some oil in a large pan, and pipe out the batter in spirals over it. Fry the jalebis till they're golden brown, and serve hot. 
Mango 
What better way to welcome spring and summer than with these mango jalebis? You'll need: 1 ripe mango; 1/2 cup sugar; 1 cup flour or maida; 1 cup yogurt; 1 tsp saffron. Syrup: 1 cup sugar; 1 cup water; 1/4 tsp cardamom powder. Mango jalebis are a must-have as summer approaches. Picture courtesy: moha-mushkil.com 
Mix the flour, sugar and yogurt together to make a smooth batter, and set it aside for an hour. Cut the mango into small slices. To make the syrup, boil the ingredients together in a pan for 10 minutes. Heat oil in a separate pan. Dip the mango slices in the fermented batter. Coat them properly, and deep fry in the oil till golden brown. Soak the fried mango jalebis in the syrup for a few minutes, take them out, and serve them hot. 
Whether it's made of fruits, chocolate or chhena, jalebis are a must-have before you bid goodbye to winters completely.
